newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico preparing tender for new toll system.
newsitem.headline: Mexico preparing tender for new toll system.

text.p: Mexico is seeking bids on a project to overhaul of the system used to collect tolls along its federal highways and bridges, the government said Tuesday.
The project is being opened to international companies, with the winner building the system and handing it back to the government.
"The project is to renovate the toll collection system to be more efficient and convenient," said an official at the Federal Bridge and Highway Authority (Capufe), who declined to be named.
"The winning company is expecting to install the latest technology, perhaps with cash debit cards or similar electronic payments," he said.

Capufe manages Mexican highways that have not been concessioned to private operators. Tolls on federal routes and bridges tend to be less expensive than the private highways, and can run about $20 for a 200-mile (320 km) road trip.
The government agency published the bidding guidelines in foreign newspapers and on the Internet. Capufe officials declined to say how much the project was expected to cost.
A decision on the winning bidder is expected at the end of November or in December, Capufe said in the paid announcements.
